attributes.magic: ELF 32-bit MSB executable, MIPS, MIPS-I version 1 (SYSV), statically linked, stripped

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects programs that connect to known malware callback ports based on statistical analysis from two different sandbox system databases

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis: The sample is a DDoS botnet agent, likely a variant of Gafgyt or Mirai, targeting MIPS-based Linux systems. It exhibits several classic malware behaviors: (1) runtime string and data decryption via XOR-based loops in sub_400e50; (2) daemonization using fork and setsid syscalls; (3) competitive survival logic that scans the /proc filesystem to identify and terminate rival malicious processes (sub_4090f8, sub_408ea4); (4) system profiling by parsing /proc/cpuinfo and /proc/stat to determine core counts and architecture details; and (5) command-and-control (C2) communication using a custom HTTP implementation (sub_40aa48). The presence of multiple packet-crafting routines (e.g., sub_408188, sub_408540, sub_407730) designed for TCP/UDP flooding further confirms its primary function as a DDoS tool.
